children.subject: Thanks for your advice! I'd appreciate more from other fellows

From what I know, every student has to take those three classes to declare the major. You might not get approval to substitute the class you took for 61b since it was probably not pre-approved by berkeley as a substitute like how classes at CA community colleges are. Also cs188 is not really an intro to the AI that is popular right now that is more math heavy. You would want cs189 for that, and cs188 is not a prerequisite.

I would just take 61a and 61b since they are very good classes and you learn a lot doing it, and if they are easy for you then that is normal for people I know who had a lot of prior experience.
Every student except transfer students who maybe took an equivalent class at community college
Just to make clear. Are you saying that CS188 is not as math-heavy as CS189? Or the opposite?

(Disclaimer: I'm EECS so I don't know L&S policies) Don't you need to take 61A, 61B, and 70 to declare the major if you're L&S? Even if you don't have to take 61AB, putting all your eggs in one basket with trying for a B+ in CS70 (most ppl consider this the most difficult of the three) may not be wise. My advice is to enjoy your first semester at Cal, get involved in research, recruit, etc., and don't take the toughest courseload your first semester.
the course content for 188 is publicly available on edge.edx.com
CS70 would be no lighter than any other classes from what I learned. Maybe I'll try.
It seems you're enrolling in 61C and 188 during the summer. Why not enroll in CS70 instead? Two technicals during the summer is a lot of work.

Thanks. It is 47B. For your roommate's situation, I thought it's because 61A had something about functional programming or stuffs like that. I didn't learn anything about these: intro classes at other schools are probably focusing more on objected-oriented things. I'm not quite sure. Maybe I'll be taking 61A and B.

My roommate freshman year was in a similar situation--he had taken equivalents to 61AB elsewhere.  I know he still had to take 61A here (something something it's taught differently from at other colleges something something), but was able to just do the self-paced course for 61B (I think it's called 47B?  Not 100% sure on the number.)  So at least from an administrative standpoint, that's probably where you stand.

history.content:
Hi guys, I'm Jingkang Zhang, a newly admitted L&S freshman planning to major in CS. Last summer, I took CS106B at Stanford (their 106A and 106B are like 61A and 61B at Berkeley) and got an A. Now I am deciding what classes to take this summer (and fall) and have two questions.

1. Can I skip 61A and 61B? I'm concerned with two aspects: first is administrative - will I be given credits for these two classes if I skip them and will I be able to declare CS major as normal after completing CS70?; second is academic - would you recommend me skipping 61A and 61B and go for other classes, or studying the similar materials again? What is true is 61B is in Java, but I never coded in Java, because Stanford 106B was in C++.

2. I am actually already enrolled in CS61C and CS188. I know it's a little bit bold, but when I was enrolling in classes for summer, I didn't expect I should be admitted to Cal as an undergraduate, so I wanted to try something interesting and challenging. Now considering a potential harm on my GPA, I'm a bit unsure of my enrollment. Can anybody help me decide whether to take on CS188 - Intro to AI? I know some Python and have confidence with the language. However, I never took CS70, which is said to be a prerequisite. But I'll be able to self-study some CS70 before summer classes (I know CS70 is pretty difficult as I looked through their first lectures). Can anyone who has done both tell me how CS70-dependent or math-heavy CS188 is?

Thanks a lot!
history.subject: Can I skip 61A and 61B? Should I take CS188?
